Beneath an oak, whose blasted form</br>Rose on Plinlimmon's summit grey,</br>Bare to the wild unpitying storm,</br>The dying harper lay.</br>His cheek was pale, parch'd was his tongue,</br>His hoary head dejected hung;</br>Wild wand'ring on each gale that blew,</br>His scatt'ring locks dishevell'd flew.</br>He mourn'd each joy, each blessing fled,</br>Country lost, his brethren dead;</br>For o'er each hill, each lonely plain,</br>A tyrant spread his hateful reign;</br>And still from vales that lay afar</br>Echoed the sullen sound of war;</br>And still the blaze ascending high</br>Illumin'd all the glowing sky.</br>Through all the desolated scene</br>He turn'd an anxious eye in vain—</br>No wand'rer came, no friend was near,</br>To wipe away the trickling tear;</br>No voice, whose accents might impart</br>A shade of comfort to his heart—</br>But Piety's celestial pow'r</br>Shone sweetly on that awful hour;</br>A ray of sacred light was giv'n,</br>That shew'd the op'ning joys of heav'n;</br>And still that harp, renown'd of yore,</br>Within his feeble arms he bore;</br>And once again (a transient gleam)</br>A spark of inspiration came.</br>Again his fingers dar'd to try</br>The trembling chords of extasy;</br>But vanish'd was that heav'nly art</br>That once could strike the throbbing heart—</br>Past was that echo, loud and clear,</br>That held the captivated ear.

"UIlin, thy soothing strain no more</br>Shall rouse the rural throng;</br>Nor glen, nor grove, nor mountain hoar,</br>Again shall echo to thy song.</br>At length the vital tide retires,</br>At length the fading spark expires;</br>Through ev'ry nerve, through ev'ry vein,</br>I feel a dreary chillness reign</br>Involving darkness spreads around,</br>And all is solitude profound.</br>Oh!  see the bier — oh!  mark the throng</br>In slow procession pass along:</br>Solemn resounds the warning knell—</br>The gloomy grave appears — Vain fleeting world, farewell!

"And sure that sweetly-pleasing strain,</br>That warm'd the sinking soul with holy fire,</br>Rose as the music of the heav'nly choir;</br>And hark!  it sounds again!</br>O'er yonder skies</br>Now turn thine eyes,</br>And see what varying views arise!</br>Aloft behold</br>The gates of gold</br>The circling courts of heav'n unfold!</br>Around them pours a dazzling stream of day;</br>And lo!  descending on the sparkling plain,</br>Cutting with airy plume the blue serene,</br>The messenger of fate pursues his way.</br>His awful air, his form divine,</br>Declare him of the seraph line:</br>Ambrosial tints his waving wings adorn,</br>Light as the genial gales of morn:</br>Around his path, around his way,</br>Mark how the glancing lightnings play!</br>His course at pleasure see him changing,</br>O'er the fair fields of ether ranging,</br>Through distant tracts the prospect bending,</br>And thence again at ease descending;</br>See!  now he turns — and now he steers</br>Where yonder sunny cloud appears;</br>Thence, wheeling from the clear cerulean height,</br>Down the wide cope of heav'n at once he bends his flight.

"Nearer he draws, and nearer still,</br>In awful majesty expos'd,</br>His solemn tidings are disclos'd:</br>Rever'd, oh Heav'n, be thy gracious will!</br>Oh!  thou, thus sent from scenes on high,</br>Conclude at once this ling'ring strife;</br>Dissolve each bond, each earthly tie,</br>And snatch me from the ills of life!</br>Reveal'd by thee,</br>Methinks I see</br>The forms that fill futurity;</br>Methinks I hear the hallow'd throng</br>Pour the warm extatic song;</br>One ardent thought, one glowing soul,</br>Appears to animate the whole.</br>Arising still, the solemn sound</br>Sweeps the etherial dome around;</br>Each look, each voice, each beaming eye</br>Joins the full flow of harmony:</br>To them the blissful boon is giv'n,</br>The joy, the love, the light of heav'n;</br>To them the spot where, clad in charms divine,</br>Thrones, donimations, pow'rs, and blazing seraphs, shine.

"Misfortune, now thy fleeting sway,</br>Thy frowns are rendered vain;</br>The transient terrors of thy reign</br>Are but the evils of a day:</br>The ling'ring pang, the struggling sigh,</br>The tear that trembles from the eye,</br>Affliction's ever-changing form,</br>Each care that rends the tortur'd heart,</br>Like summer's transitory swarm,</br>Like meteors mingling with the storm,</br>All, all at once depart:</br>Thick hov'ring round</br>Yon chasm profound,</br>Alternate disappear</br>The joys, the pains,</br>The varying scenes,</br>That mark this mortal sphere.</br>But see!  the sacred form from realms of day</br>Bends the bright eye on heav'n, and warns me far away.

"Where is that dread appalling pow'r—</br>Where is that spectre, stern and bare,</br>The grisly phantom of despair,</br>The guardian of this awful hour?</br>Oh!  what is death? — a flitting scene,</br>A trivial stroke, a partial pain.</br>'Tis guilt alone whose aching eye</br>Should close against eternity;</br>'Tis guilt on whose afflicting end</br>The tear, the groan, should still attend.</br>Let Virtue guide thy pilgrimage beneath,</br>Thy youth to Piety be giv'n,</br>And Faith shall lead thy falt'ring steps to heav'n,</br>And Peace shall smooth the low'ring brow of death.</br>Oh!  learn to seek the tranquil train</br>That bend to Reason's placid reign:</br>Mild Charity, with melting eye;</br>Devotion, ardent and sincere;</br>And steady Hope, that looks on high—</br>These shall direct thy progress here;</br>These shall through life their sacred pow'r employ,</br>And deck the final hour with happiness and joy.

"Strike the resounding string again,</br>And pour aloud the solemn strain;</br>Let joy, let transport touch the lyre</br>With native force, with native fire!</br>On Rapture's rising wings I fly!</br>I trace the road to realms on high!</br>'Tis past — 'tis o'er—</br>The glittering shore,</br>The world of light and life appears:</br>Ye heav'nly hosts, convey me hence—</br>Oh!  lift me to the spheres!</br>'Tis silence all — the falt'ring song</br>No more the echoing hills prolong;</br>The trembling nerve, the palsied hand,</br>No more the yielding wires command;</br>The votive harp, no longer struck,</br>At once his loos'ning grasp forsook;</br>His bosom heav'd a parting groan—</br>The spring, the source of life was gone!</br>His voice, was weak, his eye was dim;</br>Sank was each pulse, and stiff each limb;</br>The blood was chill'd in ev'ry vein;</br>And Death — all conqu'ring Death!  frown'd on the fatal scene.</br>
